revision.text:
{{Infobox comedian | name = Al Madrigal | image = MADRIGAL.jpg | caption = | pseudonym = | birth_name = Alessandro Liborio Madrigal | birth_date = {{birth date and age|mf=yes|1971|7|4}} | birth_place = [[San Francisco, California]], United States | medium = [[stand-up comedy|Stand-up]], [[television]], [[film]] | genre = [[Observational comedy]], [[satire]] | subject = [[American culture]], [[human behavior]], [[family]], [[fatherhood]], [[cultural assimilation]] | influences = | influenced = | spouse = | notable_work = | signature = | website = [http://www.almadrigal.com/ AlMadrigal.com] | footnotes = }}
'''Alessandro Liborio''' "'''Al'''" '''Madrigal''' (born July 4, 1971)<ref name=TheCaptain>[http://www.cbs.com/primetime/the_captain/bio/al_madrigal/bio.php "'Welcome to The Captain,' Al Madrigal bio," CBS.com] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090126202308/http://www.cbs.com/primetime/the_captain/bio/al_madrigal/bio.php |date=2009-01-26 }}</ref> is an American comedian and actor. He was a regular correspondent on ''[[The Daily Show with Jon Stewart]]'' and is a co-founder of the [[All Things Comedy]] podcast network, alongside [[Bill Burr]]. He is known for his co-starring roles in the [[CBS]] prime-time situation comedies ''[[Gary Unmarried]]'' and ''[[Welcome to The Captain]]'', as well as [[NBC]]'s ''[[About a Boy (TV series)|About A Boy]]''.<ref name=TheCaptain /> He was a regular sketch performer on ''[[The Late Late Show (CBS TV series)|The Late Late Show]]''<ref>{{IMDb name|1371339}}</ref> with [[Craig Ferguson]], and has also appeared on ''[[Conan (talk show)|Conan]]'' and ''[[Jimmy Kimmel Live!]]''. Madrigal is a series regular in the [[Showtime (TV network)|Showtime]] dark comedy ''[[I'm Dying Up Here]]''.
==Early life== Madrigal was born in [[San Francisco, California]]. He grew up in San Francisco's [[Sunset District, San Francisco, California|Inner Sunset District]], where his neighbors included future comedians [[Michael Pritchard (comedian)|Mike Pritchard]] and [[Margaret Cho]]. He is of [[Mexicans|Mexican]] (from [[Tijuana]]) descent.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.sfgate.com/entertainment/article/Al-Madrigal-to-play-the-Punch-Line-3271245.php |title=Al Madrigal to play the Punch Line |author=Tamara Straus |publisher=San Francisco Chronicle |accessdate=2013-06-25 |date=March 4, 2010}}</ref><ref>[https://twitter.com/almadrigal/status/413468097345880065 Twitter]</ref> He attended Ecole Notre Dame Des Victoires,<ref name=":0">{{Citation|last=Comedy Central|title=This Is Not Happening - Al Madrigal - Becoming a Latino Comic - Uncensored|date=2016-03-21|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=pgsRw4M6Ogo&feature=youtu.be|accessdate=2018-01-16}}</ref> a private Catholic school in San Francisco that emphasizes instruction of French language and culture.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.ndvsf.org/school/about/|title=About|date=2015-10-22|work=Ecole Notre Dame des Victoires|access-date=2018-01-16|language=en-US}}</ref> He attended [[St. Ignatius College Preparatory]] High School for the class of 1989. He then attended the [[University of San Francisco]], but dropped out shortly afterward.
Madrigal worked for 10 years in a human resources staffing agency run by his family, where one of his main responsibilities was firing people. He often worked humor into the job. For example, he once called a man into his own office and started shouting racial epithets while doing a Nicolas Cage impression. He credits his experiences at the staffing company with preparing him for stand-up comedy: "I was in so many scary situations ... by the time I got on stage, I had no stage fright. Speaking in front of a group was nothing."<ref>{{cite web|last1=Borrelli|first1=Christopher|title=Al Madrigal: A Comic Who Knows How to Let Go|url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/2013-08-01/entertainment/ct-ent-0801-al-madrigal-20130801_1_john-hodgman-comic-al-madrigal|website=Chicago Tribune|publisher=chicagotribune.com|accessdate=31 May 2015}}</ref> In 1998, he decided to pursue a full-time career in comedy.<ref>[http://www.latinostandup.com/pages/almad.html “Al Madrigal,” LatinoStandup.com] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080727003611/http://www.latinostandup.com/pages/almad.html |date=2008-07-27 }}</ref>
==Career== ===Stand-up comedy=== Madrigal’s stand-up comedy is story-based, centering on his personal life, family, and the confusion caused by his multiethnic background.<ref>{{cite web|last1=George|first1=Doug|title=In English, Madrigal is doing just fine|url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/2009-07-31/entertainment/0907290432_1_comedy-arts-festival-madrigal-mexican|website=Chicago Tribune|publisher=chicagotribune.com|accessdate=1 June 2015}}</ref> Early in his comedy career, he was often pigeonholed as a “Latino comic.” Madrigal says he has been criticized as not being Latino enough, such as for not speaking Spanish.<ref name="V Digital Services">{{cite web|last1=Minazad|first1=Orly|title=THE DAILY SHOW CORRESPONDENT AL MADRIGAL IS FIGHTING LATINO STEREOTYPES — WITH COMEDY|url=http://www.laweekly.com/arts/the-daily-show-correspondent-al-madrigal-is-fighting-latino-stereotypes-with-comedy-5534030|website=LA Weekly|publisher=V Digital Services|accessdate=1 June 2015}}</ref><ref name=":0" />
Madrigal began his career in San Francisco's [[comedy club]]s, both as a solo performer and as a member of the sketch group Fresh Robots, which he co-founded. In 2002, he enjoyed his first major exposure in two comedy festivals: [[SF Sketchfest]], as part of Fresh Robots,<ref>[http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/chronicle/archive/2002/01/03/DD29268.DTL&type=printable "Jokers Run Wild," January 3, 2002]</ref> and the "New Faces" showcase of the [[Just for Laughs Festival]] in [[Montreal]].<ref name=BG>[http://www.boston.com/ae/theater_arts/articles/2008/06/27/hes_starting_over____again/ "He's Starting Over – Again," ''The Boston Globe'', June 27, 2008]</ref>
In 2004, Madrigal won a jury award for best stand-up comedian at the [[U.S. Comedy Arts Festival]] in [[Aspen, Colorado]]. After winning the award, he signed a talent holding deal with [[CBS]].<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20070808113343/http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/hr/search/article_display.jsp?vnu_content_id=1000797090 "Comedy ice," ''The Hollywood Reporter'', March 1, 2006]</ref>
Madrigal's ''[[Comedy Central Presents]]'' half-hour special premiered in July 2005. In April 2013, Madrigal’s first one-hour special, "Why Is The Rabbit Crying?," also premiered on Comedy Central. The special was named one of the top 10 comedy specials of 2013 by both ''[[Westword]]'' and ''[[The Village Voice]]'' and was praised for "deconstructing stereotypes rather than enforcing them" and "milking incongruity between expectations and reality to hilarious effect."<ref>{{cite web|last1=Graham|first1=Byron|title=Ten Best Comedy Specials of 2013|url=http://www.westword.com/arts/ten-best-comedy-specials-of-2013-5798899|website=Westword|publisher=Denver Westword, LLC|accessdate=10 June 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Frank|first1=Aaron|title=Top 10 Stand-Up Comedy Specials of 2013|url=http://www.villagevoice.com/music/top-10-stand-up-comedy-specials-of-2013-6593202|website=The Village Voice|publisher=Village Voice, LLC|accessdate=10 June 2015}}</ref>
Madrigal taped his latest stand up special, "Shrimpin' Ain't Easy" in December 2016 in the Masonic Lodge at [[Hollywood Forever Cemetery]]. Directed by [[Neal Brennan]], the special will premier on [[Showtime (TV network)|SHOWTIME]] in 2017.
Madrigal has been a guest on ''[[Jimmy Kimmel Live!]]'' and ''[[The Late Late Show with Craig Ferguson]]''. He appeared on ''[[The Tonight Show]]'' with [[Conan O'Brien]] on July 8, 2009.<ref>[http://www.tonightshowwithconanobrien.com/video/clips/al-madrigal-070809/1133907/] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090712004122/http://www.tonightshowwithconanobrien.com/video/clips/al-madrigal-070809/1133907/ |date=July 12, 2009 }}</ref> He later appeared on Conan's TBS Show, ''[[Conan (talk show)|Conan]]'', on May 10, 2011.<ref>[http://teamcoco.com/video/10289/comedian-al-madrigal-knows-how-to-pick-em Comedian Al Madrigal Knows How To Pick Em - Video @ Teamcoco.com<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
===Acting=== [[File:Al Madrigal by Gage Skidmore.jpg|right|upright|thumb|Madrigal performing at Politicon in 2016.]] In 2003, Madrigal successfully auditioned for a starring role on ''The Ortegas'', a comedy series for the [[Fox Network]]. The series, which was based on the [[BBC]] comedy ''[[The Kumars at No. 42]]'', cast Madrigal as the son of a [[Mexican American]] family in California who hosts a TV talk show from a studio he operates in the backyard of his parents' home.<ref>[http://www.variety.com/article/VR1117892338?refCatId=1681 "Al Madrigal: 'The Ortegas'" ''Variety'', September 11, 2003]</ref> However, the network dropped the series from its schedule before broadcasting any of its six filmed episodes.<ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/2003/10/06/business/media-fox-drops-the-ortegas-but-insists-the-show-has-not-been-canceled.html "Fox Drops 'The Ortegas' but Insists the Show Has Not Been Canceled," ''The New York Times'', October 6, 2003]</ref>
In January 2008, Madrigal was cast as a building attendant named Jesus (pronounced “Hey-Soose”) in the CBS comedy ''[[Welcome to The Captain]]''.<ref>[http://www.newsday.com/entertainment/tv/ny-ettel0204,0,1956874.story?track=rss "'The Captain' not welcome on my television," ''Newsday'', February 4, 2008]{{dead link|date=July 2011}}</ref> The series was cancelled after five episodes.<ref>[http://tvseriesfinale.com/tv-show/cbs-announces-their-2008-09-schedule-whos-been-cancelled/ "CBS Announces Their 2008-09 Schedule. Who's Been Cancelled?" TVSeriesFinale.com]</ref>
He co-starred in the CBS series ''[[Gary Unmarried]]'' (originally titled ''Project Gary''), which debuted on September 2008.<ref name=BG />
On March 14, 2013, it was announced that Madrigal would be joining NBC's ''[[About a Boy (TV series)|About A Boy]]'' as Andy, the main character's best friend.<ref>http://www.deadline.com/2013/03/al-madrigal-boards-about-a-boy-delirium-adds-a-friend-reign-casts-nastradamus/</ref> He received a 2014 [[Imagen Awards]] nomination for Best Supporting Actor for his work in the role.
Madrigal is a series regular on the [[Showtime (TV network)|Showtime]] series ''[[I'm Dying Up Here]]''. He plays a stand up comedian named Edgar in this dark comedy about Los Angeles' infamous stand up comedy scene of the 1970s. The show, which is based on a novel of the same name, is executive produced by [[Jim Carrey]].<ref>[https://variety.com/2016/tv/news/im-dying-up-here-showtime-series-1201678320/ "Jim Carrey’s 1970s Dark Comedy ‘I’m Dying Up Here’ Greenlit at Showtime," "Variety", January 12, 2016]</ref>
===''The Daily Show with Jon Stewart''=== On May 17, 2011, it was announced that Madrigal would be joining ''[[The Daily Show|The Daily Show with Jon Stewart]]''. He is often presented as the “Senior Latino Correspondent.”
Madrigal auditioned for the show on the recommendation of stand-up comedian Adam Lowitt, one of the show’s producers. Madrigal and Lowitt performed a piece at [[Carolines on Broadway|Carolines]] on Texas Representative [[Debbie Riddle]], who proposed a bill that would create state punishments for those who “intentionally, knowingly, or recklessly” hired unauthorized immigrants except for domestic workers.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Castillo|first1=Mariano|title=Texas immigration bill has big exception|url=http://www.cnn.com/2011/POLITICS/03/01/texas.immigration.bill/|website=CNN|publisher=Turner Broadcasting System, Inc.|accessdate=31 May 2015}}</ref> Madrigal later did a reading of the piece with [[Jon Stewart]], who hired him on the spot.
===All Things Comedy=== In 2012, Madrigal and comedian [[Bill Burr]] founded [[All Things Comedy]], a comedy podcast network and artist cooperative.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Espinoza|first1=Russ|title=New Model for a Funny Business|url=http://www.austinchronicle.com/arts/2015-03-13/new-model-for-a-funny-business/|website=The Austin Chronicle|publisher=Austin Chronicle Corp.|accessdate=15 May 2015}}</ref> Madrigal and Burr started the network as a way to help comedians maintain full ownership of their work.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Espinoza|first1=Russ|title=New Model for a Funny Business|url=http://www.austinchronicle.com/arts/2015-03-13/new-model-for-a-funny-business/|website=The Austin Chronicle|publisher=Austin Chronicle Corp.|accessdate=15 May 2015}}</ref> The network hosts over 50 podcasts and garners nearly 5 million listeners per month.<ref>{{cite web|last1=McGlynn|first1=Katia|title=5 Things Comedians Can Learn from Bill Burr, Al Madrigal and the Power of All Things Comedy|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2015/03/18/all-things-comedy_n_6896750.html|website=Huffington Post|publisher=TheHuffingtonPost.com, Inc.|accessdate=15 May 2015}}</ref>
At [[South by Southwest|South by Southwest 2015]], Madrigal, Burr, and comedian [[Doug Benson]] spoke on the “Owning Your Work: The Future of All Things Comedy” panel, where they “discussed the ins and outs of their operation and how they are working to help comics carve out their own paths in show business and avoid traditional gatekeepers.”<ref>{{cite web|last1=McGlynn|first1=Katia|title=5 Things Comedians Can Learn From Bill Burr, Al Madrigal and the Power of All Things Comedy|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2015/03/18/all-things-comedy_n_6896750.html|website=The Huffington Post|publisher=TheHuffingtonPost.com, Inc.|accessdate=15 May 2015}}</ref>
From 2010-2014, he co-hosted a podcast called “Minivan Men” with comedians Maz Jobrani, Aaron Aryanpur, and Chris Spencer, in which they discussed marriage, parenting, and domestic issues.<ref>{{cite web|last1=N/A|first1=N/A|title=Minivan Men|url=http://allthingscomedy.com/channels/1/minivan-men|website=All Things Comedy|publisher=All Things Comedy|accessdate=15 May 2015}}</ref>
Madrigal and Burr host the “All Things Comedy Live Podcast,” which streams monthly. The podcast has featured comics including [[Sinbad (comedian)|Sinbad]], [[Nick Thune]], Felipe Esparza, [[Doug Benson]], [[Pete Holmes]], [[Ian Edwards (comedian)|Ian Edwards]], and [[Fred Stoller]].<ref>{{cite web|last1=N/A|first1=N/A|title=All Things Comedy Live Podcast|url=http://allthingscomedy.com/channels/55/all-things-comedy-live-podcast|website=All Things Comedy|publisher=All Things Comedy|accessdate=15 May 2015}}</ref>
===''Half Like Me''=== On January 22, 2015, Madrigal's one-hour comedic documentary special, ''Half Like Me'', premiered on [[Fusion (TV channel)|Fusion]]. The program follows Madrigal on his quest to get closer to his Mexican roots in preparation for a family reunion in Tijuana, Mexico.<ref name="Los Angeles Times Media Group">{{cite web|last1=Lloyd|first1=Robert|title=Critic's Pick TV Picks: 'Nightly Show,' 'Half Like Me,' 'Nova,' 'The Fall,' more|url=http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/tv/showtracker/la-et-st-tv-picks-nightly-show-half-like-me-togetherness-nova-fall-20150117-column.html|website=LA Times|publisher=Los Angeles Times Media Group|accessdate=9 June 2015}}</ref> During the course of the program Madrigal explores different aspects of Latino culture in the U.S. ''[[The A.V. Club]]'' called it "solid and thought-provoking" while the Los Angeles Times listed the special as a "Critic's Pick".<ref name="Los Angeles Times Media Group"/><ref>{{cite web|last1=Kallison|first1=David|title=Al Madrigal’s new special explores how the other half lives|url=http://www.avclub.com/review/al-madrigals-new-special-explores-how-other-half-l-214050|website=A.V. Club|publisher=Onion Inc.|accessdate=9 June 2015}}</ref> In an interview with [[LA Weekly]], Madrigal said, "'people are actually reaching out and wanting to teach this in their classrooms.'"<ref name="V Digital Services"/>
